makers.displaydate: 1606–1669; born Leiden, Netherlands; died Amsterdam, Netherlands
makers.displaymaker: Rembrandt van Rijn, 1606–1669; born Leiden, Netherlands; died Amsterdam, Netherlands

texts.textentryhtml: Born in Germany, Jan Lutma (about 1584–1669) settled in Amsterdam, where he became a master gold- and silversmith. In this sensitive portrait by Rembrandt, the elderly craftsman is seated in an elaborate carved armchair, accompanied by the tools and creations of his trade: a hammer and a pot containing punches along with a chased-silver bowl rest on the table while Lutma holds a candlestick. The subtle play of the warm, diffuse light from the window and the cast shadows on Lutma’s figure imparts an atmospheric intimacy that is missing from the more formal portrait by his son Jan Lutma the Younger in the same year. In 1656, Lutma recovered from a temporary deterioration of his eyesight. It is thought that he may have commissioned both prints to use as announcements that he was still (or again) working in the craft that had brought him fame and fortune.
